description:
Asterias amurensis, commonly known as the Northern Pacific seastar or the Japanese Common Starfish, is a species of starfish (echinoderm) native to the western Pacific Ocean. It is a large, predatory starfish that can grow up to 50 cm in diameter.

The body of Asterias amurensis is typically dark red or purple in color, with five long, tapering arms. The upper surface of the arms is covered in small, sharp spines, which help the starfish to grip and move across surfaces. The underside of the starfish has a central mouth surrounded by rows of tube feet, which it uses to move and capture prey.

Asterias amurensis is an important predator in its native ecosystems, feeding on a variety of bivalve mollusks, such as oysters and mussels. It is also known to prey on other starfish species and some small crustaceans. The species plays a key role in maintaining the balance of marine communities in its natural range.

Due to its large size and high population densities, Asterias amurensis has become an invasive species in some regions where it has been introduced, such as the west coast of the United States and parts of Australia. Its introduction has had significant ecological and economic impacts in these areas, as it can outcompete and displace native starfish species and cause damage to commercially important bivalve populations.
